text:
Monday’s Travel News and Tips JULY 6, 2015 A room at the Lanesborough in London. 
Advertisement Our weekday morning digest that includes consumer news, deals, tips and anything else that travelers may want to know. A NEW LOOK FOR THE LANESBOROUGH IN LONDON The Lanesborough in the Knightsbridge neighborhood in London was one of the city’s top luxury hotels when it closed its doors in December 2013 for a renovation. Now, following a nearly $100 million makeover, it will reopen on July 15 for overnight guests. The refurbishment sticks to the elegant Regency-style décor the 93-room property has been known for since it opened in 1991, and was led by Alberto Pinto, the well-regarded interior design studio. Guest rooms have new period-style wood furniture and silk fabrics but also emphasize technology, according to the managing director, Geoffrey Gelardi. “We wanted to stick to our original aesthetic but also want to feel modern,” he said. See More » To his point, each room has three Sony Xperia Z2 tablets — one on either side of the bed to control temperature and lights and a third on the desk where guests can view amenities, order room service and make housekeeping requests. If the room lights are off, night lights automatically turn on when guests’ feet touch the floor, and room keys have long-range readers that unlock doors from several feet away — even if they’re in a pocket or handbag. Public spaces including the cigar bar were also redone with new furnishings, and the restaurant Céleste is under the direction of the three-Michelin-starred chef Eric Fréchon from France and his protégé Florian Favario. Rates from £715 (about $1,085) a night. COOKING AND TASTINGS AT A MENDOZA RESORT Argentina’s wine region of Mendoza is a popular tourist destination during the country’s warm-weather months from November through March, but Cavas Wine Lodge, a Relais & Châteaux property at the foothills of the Andes, has an offer to also lure in travelers during the mild winters. From July 1 through Sept. 14, guests who make a reservation get several extras, including a cooking class with the hotel chef featuring Argentine specialties like grilled steak with chimichurri sauce, a tasting of locally produced olive oils, a sunset bird-watching excursion, a pruning lesson in the 55 acres of on-site vineyards, and a dessert and sparkling wine pairing. Rates from $390 a night. DISCOUNTS ON PALM BEACH ATTRACTIONS Discover the Palm Beaches, the official tourism organization for Palm Beach County, Fla., recently introduced the “ Discover Pass, ” which offers up to a 38 percent discount on four popular attractions in the area. Travelers pay $59.99 ($39.99 for children ages 3 to 12) to get one-time entry into the Lion Country Safari, a drive-through experience with more than 900 wild animals; the Palm Beach Zoo and Conservation Society, which has more than 1,400 animals; and the South Florida Science Center and Aquarium, where highlights include the 3,500-gallon predator tank with sharks and barracudas. A 90-minute ride on the Visit Palm Beach Sunset Sailing Cruise along Florida’s Intracoastal Waterway, to see the sunset over the West Palm Beach skyline as well as the palatial mansions on Palm Beach Island, is also part of the deal.
